chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text:
In this problem, we have to analyze two factors:

1. Whether or not the original price would be more than the price of $24,099.

2.  Whether or not the price in 2026. would be greater or lower than the price of today.

The most fundamental concept in the field of financial management is known as the "**time value of money**," which states that money obtained now is worth more than the same amount of money that will be received in the future. The reason for this is because there is the opportunity for the money to accumulate interest. As a consequence of this, the same amount of money received today will be worth more in the future.

**1.** The answer is yes, the price will be higher than the initial price of $24,099 since it is common practice for stockholders to anticipate that the initial amount will have a bigger value in the future so that they may sell it on the stock market for a higher price. For example, if one were to invest $100 at a rate of interest of 10% today, that same amount of money would be equivalent to $110 over a period of one year.

**2.** In 2026., the price would likely be greater due to the security's price trending approaching $100,000 as time passes. This increase is just a reflection of the fact that money becomes more valuable over time. As more time passes, the amount of time remaining until receiving decreases, which results in an increase in the current value. On the other hand, if the stock's financial performance is unsatisfactory, the price of the security may fall.

In this exercise, we assume that the security offered by TMCC is traded in the NYSE (New York Stock Exchange). We need to answer whether the security would have the same market value after a few years or not.

We know the following values: 

|||
|--|--|
Security's orginal value (2008) |$24,099 
r	|4.86%
Years until future cash flow | 30
Future cashflow | $100,000
We know that the return rate (r) of this security in 30 years is **4.86%**, calculated in previous exercises.

First, we need to answer whether the market price of the security would be the same after years passed since it was issued. The answer is no. If a buyer is interested in buying the security they will need to pay a prime that is going to account for the interest accumulated during the years that passed. This happens because the seller is not willing to sell the security with no return on their money after waiting said period of time.

Now we will use the formula for Future Value (FV) to calculate the price in 2019.

$$ \begin{aligned}
FV &= {PV}{\cdot(1+r)^{t}} \\
\end{aligned}$$

*Where:*
- PV is the present value
- r is the applied rate
- t is the periods of time the rate is applied

As we can see the price should not be the same but higher in 2019 since we need to account for 11 years of accumulated interest. If we were to buy it at face value in 2019 our internal rate of return would be much higher than the 4.86% and the return rate of the seller would have been 0% on their investment.
